texts.arabic: عن سليمان بن صُرَد قال: كنت جالساً مع النبي ﷺ ورجلان يستبّان، وأحدهما قد احمر وجهه، وانتفخت أوداجه، فقال رسول الله ﷺ: إني لأعلم كلمة لو قالها لذهب عنه ما يجد، لو قال: أعوذ بالله من الشيطان الرجيم ذهب عنه ما يجد. أخرجه البخاري، كتاب بدء الخلق، باب صفة إبليس وجنوده (3/ 1195)، رقم: (3108)
texts.translation: (Al-Bukhariand Muslim)

texts.text: Abu Hurairah (May Allah be pleased with him) reported: Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said, The strong man is not one who is good at wrestling, but the strong man is one who controls himself in a fit of rage.
texts.arabic: عن أبي هريرة رضي اللّه عنه؛ أن رسول اللّه صلى اللّه عليه وسلم قال‏:‏ ‏«‏ليسَ الشديدُ بالصّرعَةِ، إنما الشديدُ الذي يملكُ نفسَهُ عند الغضب‏»‏‏.‏
texts.translation: (Al-Bukhari and Muslim)

texts.text: He reported that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said, Who do you reckon to be the one who most often throws people down (in a fight)? They replied, The one whom men do not throw down. He said, No the one who throws people down is the person who controls himself when he is angry.
texts.arabic: عن ابن مسعود رضي اللّه عنه قال‏:‏ قال رسول اللّه صلى اللّه عليه وسلم‏:‏ ‏»‏ما تَعُدُّونَ الصُّرَعَةَ فيكُمْ‏؟‏ قلنا‏:‏ الذي لا تصرعُه الرجالُ، قال‏:‏ لَيْسَ بذلكَ، وَلَكِنَّهُ الَّذي يَمْلكُ نَفْسَهُ عِنْدَ الغَضَب‏»‏
texts.translation: (Reference: Al-Adab Al-Mufrad 155)

texts.text: Narrated Mu'adh ibn Anas: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: If anyone suppresses anger when he is in a position to give vent to it, Allah, the Exalted, will call him on the Day of Resurrection over the heads of all creatures, and ask him to choose any of the bright and large eyed maidens he wishes.
texts.arabic: عن معاذ بن أنس الجهني الصحابي رضي اللّه عنه أن النبيّ صلى اللّه عليه وسلم قال‏:‏ ‏«‏مَنْ كَظَمَ غَيْظاً وَهُوَ قادِرٌ على أنْ يُنَفِّذَهُ دَعاهُ اللَّهُ سُبْحانَهُ وَتَعالى على رُؤوس الخَلائِقِ يَوْمَ القِيامَةِ حتَّى يُخَيِّرَهُ مِنَ الحُورِ ما شاءَ‏»‏ قال الترمذي‏:‏ حديث حسن‏.‏
texts.translation: (Reference: Sunan Abi Dawud 4777)

chapters.name: What to say to a wife who had a fight with her husband

texts.text: Shall I not inform you about your women in Paradise? They are affable and fertile. If she becomes angry or mistreated, or if her husband becomes angry with her, she says: 'Here is my hand in your hand, I will not sleep until you are pleased.
texts.arabic: َلَاْ أُخبِرُكُم بِنِسَائِكُم فِي الجَنَّةِ؟! كُلُّ وَدُودٍ وَلُودٍ ، إِذَا غَضِبَت أَو أُسِيءَ إِلَيهَا أَو غَضِبَ زَوجُهَا ، قَالَت : هَذِه يَدِي فِي يَدِكَ ، لَاْ أَكْتَحِلُ بِغُمضٍ َحتَّى تَرضَى ) أخرجها النسائي في الكبرى (5/361) والطبراني في الكبير (19/14) والأوسط (6/301) (2/242) وأبو نعيم في الحلية (4/303) وقال الشيخ الألباني : إسناد رجاله ثقات رجال مسلم
texts.translation: This hadith was reported by Anas ibn Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) and recorded in several collections of hadith, including Al-Nasa'i in Al-Kubra (5/361), Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir (19/14) and Al-Awsat (6/301), Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilya (4/303). The chain of narrators is considered reliable by Sheikh Al-Albani.

chapters.name: Congratulation on the occasion of a birth

texts.text: Bārakallāhu laka fi ‘l-mawhūbi lak, wa shakarta ‘l-wāhib, wa balagha ashuddah, wa ruziqta birrah.
texts.arabic: بَارَكَ اللَّهُ لَكَ فِي الْمَوْهُوبِ لَكَ، وَشَكَرْتَ الْوَاهِبَ، وَبَلَغَ أَشُدَّهُ، وَرُزِقْتَ بِرَّهُ
texts.translation: May Allah bless you with His gift to you, and may you (the new parent) give thanks, may the child reach the maturity of years, and may you be granted its righteousness. (Reference: An-Nawawi, Kitdbul-'Athkarp. 349, and Sahihul-'Athkar2/7l3 by Saleem Al-Hilali)

texts.text:
«Allahumma barik feeh/feeha»
Narrated Abu Musa:I got a son and I took him to the Prophet (ﷺ) who named him Ibrahim, and put in his mouth the juice of a date fruit (which be himself had chewed?, and invoked for Allah's blessing upon him, and then gave him back to me. He was the eldest son of Abii Musa.
texts.arabic: اللهم بارك فيه
texts.translation: О Аллах, ниспошли на него/её благословения
texts.url: O Allah, bless him/her. (Reference: Sahih al-Bukhari 6198)

chapters.name: Dua to protect children from the evil eye

texts.text: «U`īthukumā bikalimāti ‘llāhit-tāmmati min kulli shaytānin wa hāmmah, wa min kulli `aynin lāmmah».
texts.arabic: كَانَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ - صلى الله عليه وسلم - يُعَوِّذُ الحَسَنَ وَالحُسَينَ أُعِيذُكُمَا بِكَلِمَاتِ اللَّهِ التَّامَّةِ مِنْ كُلِّ شَيْطَانٍ وَهَامَّةٍ، وَمِنْ كُلِّ عَيْنٍ لاَمَّةٍ
texts.translation: I seek protection for you in the Perfect Words of Allah from every devil and every beast, and from every envious blameworthy eye. (Reference: Al-Bukhari4/119)

chapters.name: When mounting an animal or any means of transport

texts.text: Bismillāh, walhamdulillāh. Subhāna ‘lladhī sakhkhara lanā hādhā wa mā kunnā lahu muqrinīn. Wa innā ilā Rabbinā lamunqalibūn. Alhamdulillāh, alhamdulillāh, alhamdulillāh, Allāhu Akbar, Allāhu Akbar, Allāhu Akbar, Subhānaka ‘llāhumma innī zalamtu nafsī, faghfir lī, fa innahu lā yaghfirudh-dhunūba illā ant.
texts.arabic: شَهدتُ عليًّا رضِيَ اللَّهُ عنهُ وأُتِيَ بدابَّةٍ ليَرْكبَها فلمَّا وضعَ رِجلَه في الرِّكابِ قالَ بسمِ اللَّهِ فلمَّا استوى على ظَهرِها قالَ الحمدُ للَّه ثمَّ قالَ {سُبْحَانَ الَّذِي سَخَّرَ لَنَا هَذَا وَمَا كُنَّا لَهُ مُقْرِنِينَ وَإِنَّا إِلَى رَبِّنَا لَمُنْقَلِبونَ} ثمَّ قالَ الحمدُ للَّهِ - ثلاثَ مرَّاتٍ - ثمَّ قالَ اللَّهُ أَكبرُ - ثلاثَ مرَّاتٍ - ثمَّ قالَ سبحانَك إنِّي ظلمتُ نفسِي فاغفِر لي فإنَّهُ لا يغفِرُ الذُّنوبَ إلَّا أنتَ ثمَّ ضحِك فقيلَ يا أميرَ المؤمنينَ من أيِّ شيءٍ ضحِكتَ قالَ رأيتُ النَّبيَّ صلَّى اللَّهُ عليهِ وسلَّمَ فعلَ كما فعَلتُ ثمَّ ضحِك فقلتُ يا رسولَ اللَّهِ من أيِّ شيءٍ ضحِكتَ قالَ إنَّ ربَّكَ يعجَبُ من عبدِه إذا قالَ اغفِر لي ذنوبي يعلَمُ أنَّهُ لا يغفرُ الذُّنوبَ غيري صحيح أبي داود الرقم: 2602
texts.translation: With the Name of Allah. Praise is to Allah. Glory is to Him Who has provided this for us though we could never have had it by our efforts. Surely, unto our Lord, we are returning. Praise is to Allah. Praise is to Allah. Praise is to Allah. Allah is the Most Great. Allah is the Most Great. Allah is the Most Great. Glory is to You. O Allah, I have wronged my own soul. Forgive me, for surely none forgives sins but You. (Reference: Abu Dawud 3/34, At-Tirmidhi 5/501. See also Al-Albani, Sahih At-Tirmidhi3/156)

chapters.name: Dua for travel

texts.text:
Allāhu Akbar, Allāhu Akbar, Allāhu Akbar, Subhāna ‘l-ladhi sakhkhara lanā hādhā wa mā kunnā lahu muqrinīn. Wa innā ilā Rabbinā lamunqalibūn. Allāhumma innā nas'aluka fī safarinā hādha ‘l-birra wat-taqwā, Wa mina ‘l-`amali mā tardā, Allāhumma hawwin `alaynā safaranā hādhā watwi `annā bu`dah, Allāhumma antas-sāhibu fis-safar, wa ‘l-khalīfatu fil-ahl, Allāhumma innī a`ūdhu bika min wa`thā'is-safar, wa ka'ābati ‘l-manzar, wa sū'il-munqalabi fil-māli wa ‘l-ahl.
(Upon returning recite the same again adding): Ā’ibūna, tā'ibūna, `ābidūn, Li Rabbinā hāmidūn.
texts.arabic: اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، {سُبْحَانَ الَّذِي سَخَّرَ لَنَا هَذَا وَمَا كُنَّا لَهُ مُقْرِنِينَ * وَإِنَّا إِلَى رَبِّنَا لَمُنقَلِبُونَ}((اللَّهُمَّ إِنّا نَسْأَلُكَ فِي سَفَرِنَا هَذَا البِرَّ وَالتَّقْوَى، وَمِنَ الْعَمَلِ مَا تَرْضَى، اللَّهُمَّ هَوِّنْ عَلَيْنَا سَفَرَنَا هَذَا وَاطْوِ عَنَّا بُعْدَهُ، اللَّهُمَّ أَنْتَ الصَّاحِبُ فِي السَّفَرِ، وَالْخَليفَةُ فِي الْأَهْلِ، اللَّهُمَّ  إِنِّي أَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ وَعْثَاءِ السَّفَرِ، وَكَآبَةِ الْمَنْظَرِ، وَسُوءِ الْمُنْقَلَبِ فِي الْمَالِ وَالْأَهْلِ))، وإذا رَجَعَ قَالَهُنَّ وَزَادَ فِيهِنَّ: آيِبُونَ، تائِبُونَ، عَابِدُونَ، لِرَبِّنَا حَامِدُونَ
texts.translation: Allah is the Most Great. Allah is the Most Great. Allah is the Most Great. Glory is to Him Who has provided this for us though we could never have had it by our efforts. Surely, unto our Lord we are returning. O Allah, we ask You on this our journey for goodness and piety, and for works that are pleasing to You. O Allah, lighten this journey for us and make its distance easy for us. O Allah, You are our Companion on the road and the One in Whose care we leave our family. O Allah, I seek refuge in You from this journey's hardships, and from the wicked sights in store and from finding our family and property in misfortune upon returning. (Upon returning recite the same again adding :) We return repentant to our Lord, worshipping our Lord, and praising our Lord.

texts.text: Sami`a sāmi`un bihamdillāhi wa husni balā'ihi `alaynā. Rabbanā sāhibnā, wa afdil `alaynā, `ā'idhan billāhi minan-nār.
texts.arabic: عن أبي هريرةأنَّ النبيَّ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عليه وَسَلَّمَ كانَ إذَا كانَ في سَفَرٍ وَأَسْحَرَ يقولُ: سَمِعَ سَامِعٌ بحَمْدِ اللهِ وَحُسْنِ بَلَائِهِ عَلَيْنَا، رَبَّنَا صَاحِبْنَا وَأَفْضِلْ عَلَيْنَا، عَائِذًا باللَّهِ مِنَ النَّارِ
texts.translation: He Who listens has heard that we praise Allah for the good things He gives us. Our Lord, be with us and bestow Your favor upon us. I seek the protection of Allah from the Fire. (Reference: Muslim 4/2086)

chapters.name: Dua of the traveller for the resident

texts.text: Astawdi`ukumu ‘llāha ‘l-ladhi lā tadī`u wadā'i`uh.
texts.arabic: عن موسى بن وردان ، قال أبو هريرة :  ألا أعلمك كلمات علمنيهن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم إذا أردت سفرا ، أو تخرج مكانا تقول لأهلك :أستودعكم الله الذي لا يخيب ودائعه. رواه ابن السني في عمل اليوم والليلة (516) وحسنه الشيخ الألباني رحمه الله في الصحيحة (16)، وينظر أيضا : السلسلة الضعيفة (1470)
texts.translation: I place you in the trust of Allah, whose trust is never misplaced. (Reference: Ahmad 2/403, Ibn Majah 2/943. See also Al-Albani, Sahih Ibn Majah 2/133)

chapters.name: Dua of the resident for the traveller

texts.text: Astawdi`ullāha dīnak, wa amānatak, wa khawātīma `amalik.
texts.arabic: عن قزعة قال‏:‏قال لي ابن عمرَ رضي اللّه عنهما‏:‏ تعالى أُودّعك كما ودّعني رسولُ اللّه صلى اللّه عليه وسلم‏:‏ ‏»‏أسْتَوْدِعُ اللَّهَ دِينَكَ وأمانَتَكَ وَخَوَاتِيمَ عَمَلِكَ‏»‏‏.
texts.translation: I leave your religion in the care of Allah, as well as your safety, and the last of your deeds. (Reference: Ahmad 2/7, At-Tirmidhi 5/499. See also Al-Albani, Sahih At-Tirmidhi 2/155)

texts.text: «Zawwadaka ‘llāhut-taqwā, wa ghafara dhanbak, wa yassara laka ‘l-khayra haythu mā kunt»
texts.arabic: عن أنس بن مالك قال جاءَ رجُلٌ إلى النَّبِيِّ صلَّى اللَّهُ عليهِ وسلَّمَ فقالَ يا رسولَ اللَّهِ إنِّي أريدُ سفرًا فزوِّدني. قالَ زوَّدَك اللَّهُ التَّقوى قالَ زِدني. قالَ وغفرَ ذنبَك قالَ زدني بأبي أنتَ وأمِّي. قالَ ويسَّرَ لَك الخيرَ حيثُما كنتَ صحيح الترمذي الرقم: 3444 خلاصة حكم المحدث : حسن صحيح
texts.translation: May Allah give you piety as your provision, forgive your sins, and make goodness easy for you wherever you are. (Reference: At-Tirmidhi. See Al-Albani, Sahih At-Tirmidhi, 3/155)

chapters.name: Pronunciation of Takbir and Tasbih while travelling

texts.text: Jabir said that when they went up to high ground they said, “Allahu akbar!” and when they descended they said, “Subhanallah”»
texts.arabic: حَدَّثَنَا مُحَمَّدُ بْنُ يُوسُفَ حَدَّثَنَا سُفْيَانُ عَنْ حُصَيْنِ بْنِ عَبْدِ الرَّحْمَنِ عَنْ سَالِمِ بْنِ أَبِى الْجَعْدِ عَنْ جَابِرِ بْنِ عَبْدِ اللَّهِ — رضى الله عنهما — قَالَ: كُنَّا إِذَا صَعِدْنَا كَبَّرْنَا ، وَإِذَا نَزَلْنَا سَبَّحْنَا . طرفه 2994 — تحفة 2245 رواه البخاري ‏(‏2993‏)‏ ، والنسائي ‏(‏541‏)‏ ، و ‏(‏542‏)‏ ، وابن السني ‏(‏517‏)‏ ، وأخرجه أحمد والدارمي والدارقطني‏.‏‏
texts.translation: Allh is most great, Glory be to Allah. (Al-Bukhari 2993, An-Nasai in Sunan al-Kubra 10299)

chapters.name: Dua upon entering a town or village

texts.text: Allāhumma Rabbas-samāwātis-sab`i wa mā azlaln, Wa Rabba ‘l-arādīnas-sab`i wa mā aqlaln, wa Rabbash-shayātīni wa mā adlaln, wa Rabbar-riyāhi wa mā dharayn. As'aluka khayra hādhihi ‘l-qaryah, wa khayra ahlihā, wa khayra māfīhā, wa a`ūdhu bika min sharrihā, wa sharri ahlihā, wa sharri mā fīhā.
texts.arabic: صهيب رضي الله عنه ، أَنَّ النَّبِىَّ صلى الله عليه وسلم لَمْ يَرَ قَرْيَةً يُرِيدُ دُخُولَهَا إِلاَّ قَالَ حِينَ يَرَاهَا :(اللَّهُمَّ رَبَّ السَّمَوَاتِ السَّبْعِ وَمَا أَظْلَلْنَ ، وَرَبَّ الأَرَضِينِ السَّبْعِ وَمَا أَقْلَلْنَ ، وَرَبَّ الشَّيَاطِينِ وَمَا أَضْلَلْنَ ، وَرَبَّ الرِّيَاحِ وَمَا ذَرَيْنَ ، فَإِنَّا نَسْأَلُكَ خَيْرَ هَذِهِ الْقَرْيَةِ وَخَيْرَ أَهْلِهَا ، وَنَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ شَرِّهَا وَشَرِّ أَهْلِهَا وَشَرِّ مَا فِيهَا ) رواه النسائي في السنن الكبرى (5/256) والحاكم في المستدرك (1/614) وقال : هذا حديث صحيح الإسناد ولم يخرجاه ، وابن خزيمة في صحيحه (4/150) ، وابن حبان في صحيحه (6/426) ، وحسنه الحافظ ابن حجر كما ذكره ابن علان في الفتوحات الربانية (5/145) ، وقال الهيثمي في مجمع الزوائد : (10/137) : رواه الطبراني في الأوسط وإسناده حسن . وحسنه الشيخ ابن باز في مجموع الفتاوى (26/46) ، وصححه الألباني في السلسلة الصحيحة (رقم/2759)
texts.translation:
O Allah, Lord of the seven heavens and all they overshadow, Lord of the seven worlds and all they uphold, Lord of the devils and all they lead astray, Lord of the winds and all they scatter. I ask You for the goodness of this town, and for the goodness of its people, and for the goodness it contains. I seek refuge in You from its evil, from the evil of its people, and from the evil it contains.
(Reference: Al-Hakim who graded it authentic and Ath-Tfaahabi agreed 2/100, and Ibn As-Sunni (no. 524). Al-Hafidh graded it good in his checking of Al-'Athkdr 5/154. Ibn Baz said in Tuhfatul-'Akhydr p. 37, that An-Nasa'i recorded it with a good chain of narration).

chapters.name: Stopping or lodging somewhere in travel and otherwise

texts.text: A`ūdhu bikalimāti ‘llāhit-tāmmāti min sharri mā khalaq.
texts.arabic: عن خولة بنت حكيم السُّلمية -رضي الله عنها- قالت: سمعتُ رسول الله ﷺ يقول:مَن نزل منزلًا ثم قال: أعوذ بكلمات الله التَّامات من شرِّ ما خلق؛ لم يضرّه شيءٌ حتى يرتحل من منزله ذلك. رواه مسلم
texts.translation: I seek refuge in the Perfect Words of Allah from the evil of what He has created. (Reference: Muslim 4/2080)

chapters.name: Glorification of Allah by a Traveler while Ascending and Descending

texts.text: «La ilaha ill-allahu wahdahu la sharika lahu, lahul- mulku, wa lahul-hamdu, wa Huwa 'ala kulli shay'in Qadeer. Ayibuna ta'ibuna 'abiduna li-Rabbina hamidun. Sadaq-Allahu wa'dahu, wa nasara 'abdahu, wa hazamal-ahzaba wahdah».
texts.arabic: عَنْ عَبْدِ اللَّهِ بْنِ عُمَرَ ، أَنَّ رَسُولَ اللَّهِ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ كَانَ إِذَا قَفَلَ (أي رجع) مِنْ غَزْوٍ أَوْ حَجٍّ أَوْ عُمْرَةٍ يُكَبِّرُ عَلَى كُلِّ شَرَفٍ مِنَ الْأَرْضِ ثَلَاثَ تَكْبِيرَاتٍ، وَيَقُولُ :  لَا إِلَهَ إِلَّا اللَّهُ وَحْدَهُ لَا شَرِيكَ لَهُ، لَهُ الْمُلْكُ وَلَهُ الْحَمْدُ، وَهُوَ عَلَى كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرٌ، آيِبُونَ ، تَائِبُونَ، عَابِدُونَ، سَاجِدُونَ، لِرَبِّنَا حَامِدُونَ، صَدَقَ اللَّهُ وَعْدَهُ، وَنَصَرَ عَبْدَهُ، وَهَزَمَ الْأَحْزَابَ وَحْدَهُ رواه البخاري ومسلم
texts.translation: None has the right to be worshipped but Allah, Who has no partner, to Whom the sovereignty belongs, to Whom all praise is due, and Who is Able to do all things. We are those who return (in safety), feel penitence, worship Allah, prostrate before our Rubb and praise Him. Allah has fulfilled His Promise, helped His slave (i.e., Muhammad (ﷺ)) and He Alone vanquished the Clans. (Al-Bukhari and Muslim)

chapters.name: Dua uttered when a mount stumbles or a car skids

texts.text:
«Bismillah».
Abu al-Malih reported on the authority of a man : I was riding on a mount behind the prophet (May peace be upon him). It stumbled. Thereupon I said: May the devil perish! He said: do not say; may the devil perish! For you say that, he will swell so much so that he will be like a house, and say: by my power. But say: in the name of Allah; for when you say that, he will diminish so much so that he will be like a fly.
texts.arabic: عن أبي المليح التابعي المشهور عن رجل قال‏:‏ كنتُ رديفَ النبيّ صلى اللّه عليه وسلم، فعثرت دابّته فقلتُ‏:‏ تَعِسَ الشيطان، فقال‏:‏ ‏»‏لا تَقُلْ تَعِسَ الشَّيْطانُ، فإنَّكَ إذَا قُلْتَ ذلكَ تَعاظَمَ حتَّى يَكُونَ مِثْلَ البَيْتِ، وَيَقُولُ‏:‏ بِقُوَّتِي، وَلَكِنْ قُلْ‏:‏ باسْمِ اللَّهِ، فإنَّكَ إذَا قُلْتَ ذلك تَصَاغَرَ حتى يَكُونَ مِثْلَ الذُّبابِ‏»‏ قلتُ‏:‏ هكذا رواه أبو داود عن أبي المليح عن رجل هو رَديف النبيّ صلى اللّه عليه وسلم‏.صحيح أبي داود الرقم: 4982
texts.translation: in the name of Allah. (Reference: Sunan Abi Dawud 4982)

chapters.name: Definition of the term 'al-Udhiyah' (Sacrifice)

texts.text: Language definition of al-Udhiyah Al-Udhiyah is the plural form of al-Adhahi and in linguistic terms, it means the sacrifice offered in the morning after the sunrise. See Al-Misbah al-Munir 359. Qadi 'Iyad said, It is called Udhiyah because it is offered at the time of Dhuha (the time after sunrise). See Sharh Sahih Muslim 13/109. Terminological definition of al-Udhiyah In the definition provided by jurists, the term al-Udhiyah refers to a specific animal that is offered as a sacrifice to draw closer to Allah at a specific time and under specific conditions. See Mughni al-Muhtaj 6/122, Subul al-Salam 4/160.
texts.arabic:
وروى الترمذي (1521)
عَنْ جَابِرِ بْنِ عَبْدِ اللَّهِ قَالَ : شَهِدْتُ مَعَ النَّبِيِّ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ الأَضْحَى بِالْمُصَلَّى فَلَمَّا قَضَى خُطْبَتَهُ نَزَلَ عَنْ مِنْبَرِهِ فَأُتِيَ بِكَبْشٍ فَذَبَحَهُ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ صَلَّى اللَّهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ بِيَدِهِ وَقَالَ بِسْمِ اللَّهِ وَاللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ هَذَا عَنِّي وَعَمَّنْ لَمْ يُضَحِّ مِنْ أُمَّتِي . صححه الألباني في صحيح الترمذي ( اللَّهُمَّ مِنْك ) : أَيْ هَذِهِ الأُضْحِيَّة عَطِيَّة ورزق وصل إِلَيَّ مِنْك ( وَلَك ) : أَيْ خَالِصَة لَك .انظر : الشرح الممتع (7/492) .

chapters.name: Sacrifices can only be dedicated to Allah alone

texts.text: It is important to know that any sacrificial offering, whether it is a holiday (Udhiyah) or not, can only be dedicated to the Almighty Allah, as Allah commanded His Prophet (peace be upon him): Say, 'Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds' (Quran, 6:162-163). Muslims who perform sacrificial offerings do so only in the name of Allah as an act of worship and to draw closer to Him. They do not dedicate sacrificial offerings to other deities, their ancestors, or other beings. It is reported from Ali ibn Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said, May Allah curse the one who offers a sacrifice to anyone other than Allah! (Muslim 1978). Sheikh Salih Al-Fawzan said, Sacrificial offerings can be divided into four types: First, when it is slaughtered in the name of Allah and for the sake of Allah, which is monotheism (Tawheed). Second, when it is slaughtered in the name of Allah, but not for the sake of Allah, which is polytheism in worship. Third, when it is slaughtered without the name of Allah and not for the sake of Allah, which is polytheism in seeking help from someone other than Allah and polytheism in worship. Fourth, when it is slaughtered without the name of Allah, but for the sake of Allah, which is polytheism in the dominion of Allah. (Explanation of Kitab At-Tawheed). The Quran and Sunnah clearly indicate that sacrificial offerings are one of the greatest forms of worship and submission to the Almighty. As for offering sacrificial offerings to anyone other than Allah, it is a manifestation of great polytheism. This is because offering an animal sacrifice as an act of worship cannot be dedicated to anyone other than the Almighty Allah. The act of offering a sacrificial animal is so significant that Shariah even prohibits performing it in a place where an idol stood or where polytheistic celebrations were held, even if the sacrificial offering is performed only for the sake of Allah. Sabit ibn ad-Dahhak (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that a man once made a vow to sacrifice a camel in Buana and asked the opinion of the Prophet (peace be upon him) about it. The Prophet (peace be upon him) asked, Was there any pagan idol on that spot to which people worshipped? They answered, No. The Prophet (peace be upon him) then asked, Did any gatherings of the unbelievers take place there? They answered, No, they did not. Then the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, Fulfill your vow. (Abu Dawood 3307, At-Tabarani 1/134). Note how the pure Shariah safeguards monotheism and closes all paths that could lead to polytheism!
texts.arabic: أَلَا لِلَّهِ ٱلدِّينُ ٱلۡخَالِصُۚ وَٱلَّذِينَ ٱتَّخَذُواْ مِن دُونِهِۦٓ أَوۡلِيَآءَ مَا نَعۡبُدُهُمۡ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَآ إِلَى ٱللَّهِ زُلۡفَىٰٓ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ يَحۡكُمُ بَيۡنَهُمۡ فِي مَا هُمۡ فِيهِ يَخۡتَلِفُونَۗ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ لَا يَهۡدِي مَنۡ هُوَ كَٰذِبٞ كَفَّارٞ

chapters.name: The dignity of a festive sacrifice

texts.text: For every community We appointed a rite of sacrifice so that they may pronounce the Name of Allah over the sacrificial animals He has provided for them. For your God is only One God, so submit yourselves to Him ˹alone˺. And give good news ˹O Prophet˺ to the humble. (Al-Haj: 34)
texts.arabic: أَلَا لِلَّهِ ٱلدِّينُ ٱلۡخَالِصُۚ وَٱلَّذِينَ ٱتَّخَذُواْ مِن دُونِهِۦٓ أَوۡلِيَآءَ مَا نَعۡبُدُهُمۡ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَآ إِلَى ٱللَّهِ زُلۡفَىٰٓ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ يَحۡكُمُ بَيۡنَهُمۡ فِي مَا هُمۡ فِيهِ يَخۡتَلِفُونَۗ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ لَا يَهۡدِي مَنۡ هُوَ كَٰذِبٞ كَفَّارٞ

texts.text: And yet, among the Hadiths about the virtues of Udhiyah, there are some authentic Hadiths. Thus, Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr said: As for the virtue of sacrifice, good news has been transmitted regarding this. He then quoted the following Hadith: Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: There is no better spending for Allah after upholding the ties of kinship than the shedding of blood of sacrificial animal. (Narrated in At-Tamhid 22/192, and Al-Hatib in Tarikh Al-Baghdad 3/59) Hafiz Ibn Abd al-Barr considered this Hadith to be good. (See Fath Al-Malik 7/18.) Also, in a long Hadith from Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him), it is reported that the Prophet (peace be upon him), when asked by his companions about the virtues of the Hajj ritual, said regarding the sacrifice: As for your sacrifice, a great reward is reserved for you with your Lord! (Narrated in Al-Bazzar 2/182, Ibn Hibban 963, and Abdur-Razzaq 8830.) This Hadith is good (See Sahih At-Targhib 1112). Al-Munawi reported from At-Tabari that he said: Good deeds, whether obligatory, Sunnah, or manners, despite their differences in virtues, sometimes have an advantage over each other. For how many deeds that are surpassed by other deeds become superior due to a certain time or place! And if we look at the ritual of the festive sacrifice (Udhiyah), it becomes clear that it is one of the manifestations of the rituals of Allah, and the Most High Allah said: 'And whoever honors the symbols of Allah, then it is truly from the piety of the heart.' (Quran 22:32). (See Faidh Al-Qadir 5/584)

chapters.name: The conditions for  udhiyah

texts.text: Animals suitable for festive sacrifices are only eight pairs of animals: camels, cows, sheep, and goats. Other types of animals are not acceptable for Udhiyah. Allah said, For every community, We have appointed a ritual so that they may mention Allah's name over the livestock He has given them. (Surah Al-Hajj 22:34) Imam Ash-Shafi'i said, By 'livestock' here, it means eight pairs of animals: camels, large-horned cattle, sheep, and goats. However, Al-Hasan ibn Salih and Ibn Hazm departed from this consensus, considering that antelopes, gazelles, and oryx are allowed to be sacrificed for Udhiyah. Ibn Hazm said that any animal whose meat is permissible to eat can be sacrificed for Udhiyah, based on the following Hadith: A person who performs the same complete ablution (ghusl) on Friday as he does after major impurity and then goes to the mosque for prayer in the first hour is like the one who sacrifices a camel to Allah. The one who goes for prayer later is like the one who sacrifices a cow to Allah. The one who goes even later is like the one who sacrifices a horned ram to Allah. The one who goes later than that is like the one who sacrifices a chicken to Allah. And the one who goes still later is like the one who sacrifices an egg to Allah. (Al-Bukhari 881, Muslim 850) However, other scholars objected to this argument and said, If we take this Hadith as evidence that it is permissible to sacrifice birds, then it means that it is also permissible to use eggs for festive sacrifices! After all, it is also mentioned in this Hadith as an example of reward. However, there is no disagreement that this is unacceptable!
texts.arabic: أَلَا لِلَّهِ ٱلدِّينُ ٱلۡخَالِصُۚ وَٱلَّذِينَ ٱتَّخَذُواْ مِن دُونِهِۦٓ أَوۡلِيَآءَ مَا نَعۡبُدُهُمۡ إِلَّا لِيُقَرِّبُونَآ إِلَى ٱللَّهِ زُلۡفَىٰٓ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ يَحۡكُمُ بَيۡنَهُمۡ فِي مَا هُمۡ فِيهِ يَخۡتَلِفُونَۗ إِنَّ ٱللَّهَ لَا يَهۡدِي مَنۡ هُوَ كَٰذِبٞ كَفَّارٞ

texts.text: As for the buffalo (al-jamus), there were also disagreements about whether it can be used as a sacrificial animal or not. Sheikh Ubaidullah al-Mubarakfuri said, As for the buffalo, the Hanafis and others are of the opinion that it can be used as a festive sacrificial animal. They said that the buffalo is a type of cow. And this opinion is strengthened by the fact that buffaloes are in the same position as cows when it comes to paying zakat on them, so they occupy the same position in sacrificial offerings. As evidence, they cite the Hadith: 'A buffalo is sacrificed for seven people.' This was mentioned by al-Munawi who said that it was mentioned by ad-Daylami in 'al-Firdaus'. However, for me, this question is not as straightforward as they claim. They themselves admit that a buffalo is a creature that is different from a cow because of the big and obvious differences between them. For this reason, they themselves claimed that whoever swore not to eat cow meat but ate buffalo meat did not violate their oath. And if he swore to divorce his wife, eating cow meat does not result in a divorce, but eating buffalo meat does. As for what is attributed to some Arabic language experts who said, 'A buffalo is a type of cow,' this is a clear simplification. However, the basis is to say, 'A buffalo is milked like a cow or is in the same position as a cow,' as Ibn Abi Shayba transmitted from al-Hasan al-Basri, who said, 'A buffalo is in the same position as a cow.' Therefore, a buffalo is not a cow itself. Probably when some jurists saw that Malik, al-Hasan, Umar ibn Abdul-Aziz, Abu Yusuf, Ibn Mahdi and others likened buffaloes to cows in terms of paying zakat on them, they understood from this that buffaloes belong to the cow family. But the fact that a buffalo is similar to a cow in paying zakat does not mean that it is similar to a cow in terms of sacrificial offerings, which is not a hidden fact. As for the aforementioned Hadith: 'A buffalo is sacrificed for seven people,' it is not the argument that should be relied upon because its degree of authenticity is unknown. As for me, it would be prudent for a person to limit themselves to the animals that are reliably mentioned in the Sunnah: in the words, deeds, and approval of the Prophet (peace be upon him). And one should not pay attention to what is not transmitted from the Prophet (peace be upon him) because it is not part of the religion

chapters.name: The sacrificial animal must be of a certain age

texts.text: According to Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him), the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: Do not sacrifice an animal that has not reached its age. If this becomes difficult for you, then you can sacrifice sheep that are at least six months old. Muslim 1963. Imam an-Nawawi said, This hadith indicates that it is not allowed to slaughter an animal that has not reached a certain age for a festive sacrifice, except for a ram. See Sharh Sahih Muslim 5/101. As for the age of sacrificial animals, it is known that the minimum age for a camel is five years, for a bull or cow it is two years, and for a goat or sheep it is one year. See al-Mudawwana 2/12, al-Mabsut 9/12, al-Mughni 9/348, al-Hawi 19/29. However, the Shariah made an exception for rams and sheep and allowed animals that have not reached one year of age to be sacrificed. Ukba ibn Amir (may Allah be pleased with him) said, Once we performed a festive sacrifice with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and we sacrificed six-month-old sheep. An-Nasai 4382, Al-Bayhaqi 9/270. Imam Ibn al-Jarud, Hafiz Ibn Hajar, and Sheikh Al-Albani confirmed the authenticity of the hadith. See Fathul-Bari 12/111, Irua al-Ghaleel 4/357-358. However, it is necessary to note that this is an exception and only when necessary, as indicated in the previous hadith: If this becomes difficult for you, then you can sacrifice sheep that are at least six months old. Muslim 1963. Moreover, some Salafis believed that a six-month-old ram should not be small. Ibrahim an-Nakha'i said, A ram that has not reached a year of age can be sacrificed if it is large. Refer to Al-Asr 63. Also, some people mistakenly believe that goats are also included in the analogy with sheep. Al-Bara ibn 'Azib (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: On the day of sacrifice, the Prophet (peace be upon him) addressed us with a sermon after prayer and said, 'The one who prays like us and sacrifices like us will do it correctly, and whoever sacrifices before prayer, then he has sacrificed before prayer, and it will not be considered a sacrifice at all.' Hearing this, Abu Burda (may Allah be pleased with him) said, O Messenger of Allah, I sacrificed my sheep before prayer because I knew it was a holiday today, and people will be eating and drinking, and I wanted my sheep to be the first to be sacrificed in my house. That's why I slaughtered my sheep and ate before coming to prayer. Upon hearing this, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, Your sheep can only be used for its meat. Abu Burda said, O Messenger of Allah, we have a small goat that is more valuable to me than two sheep. Can it be a substitute for me? He said, Yes, but after you, it will not be a substitute for anyone else! Bukhari 955. Thus, we see that this was an exception only for Abu Burda. Furthermore, there is no disagreement among scholars that all animals suitable for Udhiyah must reach their age, except for sheep. Imam An-Nawawi said: The ummah is unanimous that camels, cows, and goats cannot be sacrificed unless they have reached the required age. See Al-Majmu 8/394.

chapters.name: Defects that make the sacrificial animal unfit or undesirable for Udhiya

texts.text: It is reported that Al-Bara ibn 'Azib (may Allah be pleased with him) said that once the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stood up and said, It is not permissible to offer as a sacrifice four types of animals: a one-eyed animal whose defect is obvious, a sick animal whose sickness is obvious, a lame animal whose lameness is obvious, and an emaciated animal whose weakness is obvious. Ahmad 4/284, Abu Dawud 2802, at-Tirmidhi 1/283. The authenticity of this hadith has been confirmed by Imam Abu 'Isa at-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, and Al-Albani. Hafiz Ibn 'Abdul-Barr said: Regarding these four defects, all scholars agree, and I do not know of any differences regarding this. It is also known that everything that falls under a similar meaning is also related to this. If it is not permissible to offer a one-eyed animal, then a blind one is not permissible either. Or if a lame animal is not permissible, then a legless one is even more so. All of this is clear and known, and there is no disagreement among the scholars regarding this. See Fath al-Malik 7/16. An animal with these defects cannot be offered as a sacrifice, and if it is offered, it will not be counted, and there is no disagreement among the scholars regarding this. If these defects are not obvious and insignificant, then it is not forbidden to offer such animals as a sacrifice, because the hadith indicates that these defects should be clearly expressed. See as-Saylul-jarar 4/80. There are also defects that make an animal undesirable for sacrifice but not forbidden. Among these defects are a torn ear, broken horns, etc. Ali ibn Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) commanded us to pay attention to the eyes and ears of sacrificial animals. Ibn Majah 3143, Ibn Khuzaymah 2915. Sheikh Al-Albani confirmed the authenticity of this hadith. As for the severed or detached tail of a sacrificial animal, scholars have disagreed about this defect. Most scholars, including Hanafis, Malikis, and Shafi'is, prohibited sacrificing such an animal, unless it was born without a tail. However, among the supporters of this opinion, there was a slight disagreement regarding the length of the severed tail. See Hashiya Ibn Abidin 6/325, al-Hawi 15/83, Sharh al-Harashi 3/35. Hanbalis allowed sacrificing an animal without a tail, considering that there is no prohibition on this matter in Sunnah, and besides, the presence or absence of a tail does not affect the meat itself, its quantity or quality. See al-Mughni 13/372. However, if possible, it is still better to sacrifice an animal with an intact tail to avoid disagreement on this issue. If an animal has received any injury after its acquisition, it can still be offered as a sacrifice, despite the disagreement of the faqihs on this matter. The argument for this is the words of Abdullah ibn az-Zubair (may Allah be pleased with him), who, seeing a she-camel that had lost an eye and was prepared for sacrifice during the pilgrimage, said, If this happened to her after her purchase, then offer her as a sacrifice. But if this defect was present in her before purchase, then replace her. al-Bayhaqi 9/289. Hafiz al-Bayhaqi and Hafiz an-Nawawi called this hadith authentic. See Ma'rifat al-Sunan wa al-Athar 7/225, al-Majmu' 8/328. As for defects that are not mentioned in Sunnah, they do not make animals unfit, but they may be a reason for incomplete reward. See Sahih Fiqh al-Sunnah 2/373. Sacrifice is an act of worship to Allah, and Allah is Good and accepts only good. The Most High Allah said: And whoever honors the symbols of Allah, indeed, it is from the piety of hearts. (al-Hajj 22:32).

Regarding a castrated animal, there is no problem in sacrificing it, as there are many Hadiths indicating that two castrated rams that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sacrificed were castrated. Abu Rafi’ (may Allah be pleased with him) said, “The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sacrificed two black-and-white castrated rams.” Ahmad 6/8. The Hadith is authentic. See “Irua al-Ghalil” 1147. Imam al-Hattabi said, “These Hadiths indicate that castrated animals are not condemned for sacrificial offerings. However, some scholars considered it condemned because of the absence of a part of the animal's body. However, this is not a defect in the animal, as castration makes the animal's meat good and removes bad odor from it.” See “Ma’alimu-Ssunan” 2/197. As for pregnant animals, most scholars, except the Shafi'is, allowed sacrificing them because there is no prohibition on their slaughter in the Quran, Sunnah, or the words of any of the Prophet's companions, whether as Udhiyah or just for food. In a well-known encyclopedia of fiqh, it is said: Most scholars did not consider pregnancy as a defect for sacrificial offerings, unlike the Shafi'is, who explicitly stated that a pregnant animal is not suitable for sacrificial offerings. They considered that pregnancy spoils the animal's interior, and its meat becomes bad. See “Al-Mawsu’a al-Fiqhiya” 16/281. But, as mentioned earlier, most scholars did not consider pregnancy a defect in the animal, and they said that if the embryo is found alive after the animal is slaughtered, it should also be slaughtered in the name of Allah. And if the embryo is found dead after the mother is slaughtered, they still allowed eating it, relying on the following Hadith: Abu Sa’id Al-Khudri (may Allah be pleased with him) once asked the Prophet (peace be upon him), “O Messenger of Allah, when we cut open the womb of a she-camel, cow, or sheep, we find a fetus in them. What should we do? Should we eat it or throw it away?” The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, “Eat it if you wish, because the slaughter of the fetus is the slaughter of its mother.” Abu Dawud 2827, At-Tirmidhi 2/72. The Hadith is authentic. See Sahih al-Jami' 3431. Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said, Sacrificing pregnant animals is permitted as long as it is done before the end of the term of pregnancy.

chapters.name: The Time of the Festive Sacrifice

texts.text: The sacrifice of Udhiyah has a strictly defined time that starts after the Eid prayer and sermon on the Day of Sacrifice (10th of Dhul-Hijjah). Sacrificing before the Eid prayer invalidates the sacrifice. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said, The one who prays like us and slaughters his sacrifice like us is the one who belongs to us. But whoever slaughters before the Eid prayer, it is just meat that he has presented. [Al-Bukhari 955] Ibn al-Munthir said, It is unanimous that it is not allowed to offer the sacrifice of Udhiyah before sunrise on the Day of Sacrifice. See Al-Ijma 78. As for the latest time for sacrificing, there are five opinions among scholars on this matter. However, only two of them can be considered, as Hafiz Ibn 'Abdul-Barr said, because only two of these opinions are based on the opinions of the Companions. One opinion is that after the Day of Sacrifice (yawmu-n-nahr) on the 10th of Dhul-Hijjah, Udhiyah can still be performed for two more days. The second opinion is that after the day of sacrifice, it can be performed for three more days, i.e. all three days of At-Tashriq, until the 13th of Dhul-Hijjah inclusive. Regarding this, there is a hadith narrated by Jubayr ibn Mut'im (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, All the days of At-Tashriq are days of sacrifice! Ahmad 4/82, Ad-Daraqutni 4/284. However, there have been many different opinions about the authenticity of this hadith. But this hadith has many paths that strengthen each other, which is why Ibn Hibban, As-Suyuti, Al-Munawi, Al-Albani, Abdul-Qadir Al-Arna'ut, and Shu'ayb Al-Arna'ut confirmed its authenticity. See Sahih Ibn Hibban 9/166, Faidhul-Qadir 5/35, Sahih Al-Jami' 4537, Zadul-Ma'ad 2/290. This opinion is also transmitted from 'Ali and Ibn' Abbas (may Allah be pleased with them). See Zadul-Ma'ad 2/291, Nailul-Autar 5/142. Imam Ash-Shafi'i said, The one who sacrifices after sunset on the last day of At-Tashriq has no Udhiyah. See Al-Umm 2/223. Thus, the best opinion is that Udhiyah can be performed for four days. However,... (the text is cut off)

chapters.name: What to do if the date of the holiday differs from the date in Saudi Arabia?

texts.text: It is important to know that in case of disagreements about the beginning of Hajj, the day of Arafat, Eid prayers, and the day of sacrifice, it is necessary to rely on the visual fixation of the month of Dhu al-Hijjah of Saudi Arabia, as it is the country where these rites are performed and where people begin the Hajj rituals, stand on the mount of Arafat, perform Eid prayers, sacrifices, and other rituals. Therefore, all Muslims should orient themselves in specifying the day of sacrifice precisely to Saudi Arabia, and not to any other country, even if they claim that Saudi Arabia made a mistake in determining the new moon of Dhu al-Hijjah! It is reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: The day of your festival of breaking the fast is the day when you break the fast, the day of your sacrifice is the day when you offer the sacrifice, and the day of Arafat is the day when you are at Arafat. Al-Bayhaqi 5/176, Ad-Darakutni 2/163. The hadith is authentic. See Sahih al-Jami' 4224. Masruq narrated: Once I came to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, on the day of Arafat, and she asked me: 'Are you fasting?' I answered, 'No.' Then she said to her servant, 'Prepare barley porridge for him and add honey to it. If I were not fasting, I would have tasted it too.' I said, 'Nothing prevented me from observing the fast on this day except that I thought it was the day of sacrifice (on which fasting is forbidden).' Aisha said, 'Indeed, the day of sacrifice is when people offer sacrifices, and the day of breaking the fast is when people break the fast!' Abu Yusuf in Al-Asar 179, Al-Bayhaqi 4/254. Hafiz Ibn Rajab and Sheikh Al-Albani confirmed the authenticity of this report. See Ahkam al-Ihtilaf fi Ru'ya al-Hilal Dhu al-Hijjah 36, Al-Silsila al-Sahihah 1/442. Hafiz Ibn Rajab said, This asar from Aisha is highly reliable, and no one from her companions contradicted her in this. See Ahkam al-Ihtilaf fi Ru'ya al-Hilal Dhu al-Hijjah 36. In the mentioned hadith and asar, there is an indication that sacrifice should be performed and the day of Arafat should be established precisely when people do it, and who else but the pilgrims go through these rites on the appointed days in Mecca? Sheikh-ul-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said, Truly, in the collection of 'Al-Sunan' from the words of Abu Hurairah, who narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), the following Hadith is mentioned: 'Your fasting begins on the day when everyone fasts. Your 'Eid Al-Fitr is the day when everyone celebrates it. And your sacrifice is the day when everyone sacrifices.' This Hadith is narrated by Abu Dawud, Ibn Majah, and Al-Tirmidhi, who called it authentic. Also, 'Aisha reported that the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, 'The day of talking is the day when people talk, and the day of sacrifice is the day when people sacrifice.' Al-Tirmidhi mentioned this Hadith. All Muslim scholars followed this Hadith. For example, if Muslims accidentally stand on Mount Arafat (during Hajj) on the tenth of Zul-Hijjah (instead of the ninth), then this standing will be counted for them unanimously, and this day will be the day of Arafat for them. And if they accidentally do it on the eighth, then there is a disagreement about the reality of their stay on Arafat, but it is more correct that it will be valid. Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, said, 'Indeed, the day of Arafat is the day when all people know about it.' The basis of this issue is that Allah Almighty linked the determination of positions to the new moon and the month. He said, 'They ask you about the crescents. Say, They are timings for people and for Hajj' (Al-Baqarah 2: 189). The new moon (Al-Hilal) is the name of what becomes apparent and known, and if the moon appears in the sky, but people are not aware of it, then it will not be the Hilal. The same applies to the concept of the month (Al-Shahr), which comes from the word 'Al-Shuhra' (known, widespread). And if the onset of the month is not known among people, then it will not be the onset of the month. Indeed, many people make mistakes in this matter because of their assumption that if the new moon appears in the sky, then this is the beginning of the month, regardless of whether people have seen it and started counting or not. But the matter is not like that! It is necessary for the new moon to appear to people and for them to start counting. See Majmu' al-Fatawa 25/202.

Sheikhul-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah also said: Performing sacrifice on the territory of Mecca (mashair) is the foundation, and all other cities should follow Mecca in this. For this reason, the sacrifice feast ('Eid Al-Adha) is the greatest 'Eid, and the day of sacrifice is a great day of Hajj, as it combines the 'Eid associated with a place and the 'Eid associated with time. See Majmu' Al-Fatawa 24/227. Sheikh Ibn Uthaymeen said: As for sighting the crescent of Zul-Hijjah, then undoubtedly, the sighting of the city where the rituals are being performed is taken into account. And if the crescent has been sighted in that city, there is no point in observing other countries! And the point is that Hajj is associated with a specific place, and therefore, when the crescent of Zul-Hijjah is sighted in this region, the rulings associated with it are affirmed, even if all other countries contradict it (in calculating the start of Zul-Hijjah). From Fatwa Nurun 'Ala Ad-Darb No. 11. Sheikh Usman As-Salimi was asked: Should we perform the sacrifice feast (Al-Udhiya) following Saudi Arabia, even though we live in Morocco? Despite the fact that this would contradict our ruler, preempt him in performing the sacrifice, and cause other disturbances that you know about. The Sheikh replied: It is obligatory for all Muslims to follow the two Sacred Cities (Mecca and Medina) in the sacrifice feast, because the Hajj rituals are performed in these cities. Hajj and the day of 'Arafah are taken into account. After all, you fast on the day of 'Arafah, when Saudi Arabia fasts, when people, pilgrims stand on the mountain of 'Arafah. As for the ruler, he should not contradict the entire Islamic community, whether he is in Morocco or another country. Is it clear? But if you fear disturbance, if you are able to perform the sacrifice in secret on the day of sacrifice, then do so, and if you are not able, then perform the sacrifice on the second day, and there will be no blame on you. There are many days of sacrifice by the grace of Allah, this is the day of sacrifice itself, then the 11th of Zul-Hijjah, the 12th, and also, according to the correct opinion, the 13th of Zul-Hijjah, as Ash-Shafi'i and a group of scholars said. Is it clear? So, you have a choice, there is no sin on you if you postpone the sacrifice to the next day if you are afraid of unrest. There is no problem for you if you perform it with your city. However, you should feel that al-‘Id is celebrated together with Saudi Arabia. Sheikh Hisamuddin ‘Afana conveyed that Dr. Muhammad Sulaiman al-Ashkar said, Indeed, Muslims from all corners of the earth have come together in a unanimous opinion expressed in actions, following pilgrims regarding the establishment of the day of the sacrifice festival. And it is not permissible for any locality or group of people to contradict this unanimous opinion! See Fatwa Es'alunak 10/351. Therefore, Muslims around the world should only orient themselves towards Saudi Arabia in specifying the day of sacrifice (yaum an-nahr) and perform sacrifices with them, paying no attention to those who have decided to stand out and separate themselves from the Muslim community! And if we are talking about the difference in establishing the day of Arafat and the day of Sacrifice based on astronomical calculations, then all the more reason not to follow your city in this matter! Sheikh Ibn Baz was asked: In some Muslim countries, astronomical calculations are used to establish the beginning of the month of Ramadan or Shawwal, as well as the month of Dhu al-Hijjah, and the religious authorities of the city announce this. Can we rely on astronomical calculations, and are the announcements of these religious organizations accepted? Or should we rely on messages on the radio from countries that rely on visual observation? Sheikh Ibn Baz replied: It is mandatory to rely on visual observation to establish the beginning of the months of Hajj or Ramadan! As for astronomical calculations, it is not possible to rely on them. And we have already mentioned this many times and written about it many times. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned that scholars unanimously agree that astronomical calculations are not relied upon in establishing months, and that it is necessary to rely only on visual observation, not on astronomical calculations and the words of astronomers. Thus our Prophet (peace be upon him and Allah's blessings), and the righteous Salaf among his companions, may Allah be pleased with them, have informed us of this. And the consensus (ijma') has transmitted this, as we have already mentioned, from Abu al-Abbas Ibn Taymiyyah, Sheikh al-Islam, as explained by other scholars. As for those who have contradicted this among later generations, they are not given attention, even if they are known or scholars, their words on this matter are not taken into consideration, as they have gone against the Sunnah! See Fatawa Nurun 'ala ad-Darb 16/78-80.

chapters.name: Acquired a sacrificial animal, but later lost it

texts.text: If a person has acquired an animal for sacrifice, but subsequently lost it, or it died, or it was stolen, etc., then he is not obligated to do anything and purchase another animal. Tamim ibn Huwayss narrated: Once I bought a sheep in the valley of Mina for the purpose of Udhiyah, but then it got lost. When I asked Ibn 'Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) about it, he said, 'This will not harm you.' Al-Bayhaqi 9/289. The report is authentic. See Ma sahh min asar as-sahaba 3/1105. However, it should be distinguished between sacrifice associated with a vow (Nadhr) and sacrifice without a vow. Ibn 'Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: If a person acquired a camel for sacrifice, having made a vow to sacrifice it, and then it got lost or died, then he must replace it. But if it was a voluntary sacrifice (not by vow), then if he wishes, let him replace it, and if he does not wish, then let him do nothing. Malik 866. The chain of transmission is authentic. See Fiqh al-udhiyah 149.

chapters.name: One ram is sacrificed from the whole family

texts.text: Each wealthy family is enough to sacrifice one ram, even if this family consists of a hundred people. Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) reported: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) performed Udhiyah, he said, 'In the name of Allah. O Allah, accept from Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, and from the community of Muhammad,' and then he sacrificed. Muslim 1967. Imam al-Hattabi said, This Hadith is evidence that sacrificing one sheep is sufficient for one person and all members of his family, even if there are many of them! See Ma'alim al-Sunan 2/197. 'Ata ibn Yasar reported: Once Abu Ayyub al-Ansari (may Allah be pleased with him) was asked, 'How was the sacrifice performed during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)?' He replied, 'During the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), a person would sacrifice a sheep for himself and his family members, and they would eat its meat and give some of it to others until people started boasting about it and what you see happened.' Ibn Majah 3147, at-Tirmidhi 1541. Imam Abu 'Isa at-Tirmidhi, Imam an-Nawawi, and Sheikh al-Albani confirmed the authenticity of the Hadith. 'Ikrima reported: When Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him) brought a sheep for sacrifice, his family asked, 'Will the sacrifice be for us too?' And he replied, 'And for you too.' Al-Bayhaqi 9/279. Isnad is reliable. See Tahqiq Ma'rifat al-Sunan wa al-Athar 1/200. Ibn Abi ad-Dunya also reports that Ali ibn Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) sacrificed one animal for all members of his family. See 'Aun al-Ma'bud 8/5. As for the concept of family members, it includes wives and children, as well as close relatives such as parents, brothers or sisters, who live with them in the same house, participate in a common meal, or are completely dependent on them or participate equally in expenses. As for those relatives who live in separate houses or are independently financially supported from each other, it is not enough for them to sacrifice one animal. See at-Tadhkira wa al-Iklil 4/364, Fatwa Ibn Baz 18/37. If the family has the opportunity and willingness, they can sacrifice more than one animal, the main thing is that there is a correct intention and sincerity, not ostentation and boasting. It should be noted that the Hanafis considered it permissible to sacrifice one animal only for one person, and they considered the mentioned arguments to be annulled, as Imam at-Tahawi said. However, Hafiz an-Nawawi responded to this statement, saying, Scholars have said that he (at-Tahawi) was mistaken in this. Truly, annulment and specification must be affirmed on the basis of evidence, not on the basis of a simple statement! See Sharh Sahih Muslim 5/106.

chapters.name: About what relates to the slaughtering of sacrificial animals

texts.text:
Sincere intention
Allah Almighty said: Neither their meat nor blood reaches Allah. Rather, it is your piety that reaches Him. This is how He has subjected them to you so that you may proclaim the greatness of Allah for what He has guided you to, and give good news to the good-doers. (Surah Al-Hajj 22:37). An-Nawawi said: Intention is a condition for Udhiya. See Al-Majmu 8/380. Al-Kasani al-Hanafi said: Udhiya is not valid without intention, because the animal may be slaughtered simply for its meat or to get closer to Allah. See Badai'u-ssana'i 4/208.

Mercy towards the slaughtered animal Abu Umama (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever shows mercy during the sacrifice, Allah will show mercy to him on the Day of Resurrection.' Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad 381. Sheikh Al-Albani considered this Hadith to be good. Ibn 'Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: Once the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by a man who was sharpening his knife while putting his foot on the face of a sheep, while it was looking at him. The Prophet (peace be upon him) asked the man: 'Why didn't you sharpen your knife before you laid it down on the ground? Do you want to kill it twice?' At-Tabarani in Al-Kabir 3/140 and Al-Ausat 1/31. Sheikh Al-Albani confirmed the authenticity of this Hadith. Imam Ahmad said: Animals should be led to the place of slaughter gently and the knife should be hidden from them, only taking it out at the time of slaughter. See Jami'ul-'Ulumi Wal-Hikam 157. Imam An-Nawawi said: One should not slaughter one animal in the presence of another. See Sharh Sahih Muslim 13/93. It is reported from Shaddad ibn Aus (may Allah be pleased with him) that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: Verily, Allah has prescribed proficiency in all things. Thus, if you kill, kill well; and if you slaughter, slaughter well. Let each one of you sharpen his blade and let him spare suffering to the animal he slaughters. Muslim 3/1955. Performing a good sacrifice involves quickly cutting the throat and neck arteries. An-Nawawi said: Scholars agree that the animal should be placed on its left side before slaughter because it facilitates the slaughter, as the person can take the knife in his right hand and hold the animal's head in his left. See Sharh Sahih Muslim 13/122.

Turn the sacrificial animal towards the Kaaba during slaughter.According to Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him), When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) performed a sacrifice, he turned the animal towards the Kaaba. Abu Dawud 2795. Sheikh Al-Albani confirmed its authenticity. Nafi' narrated: Ibn 'Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) turned the animal towards the Kaaba during the sacrifice of Udhiyah. Malik 854. The Isnad is reliable. However, this desirability is specifically related to the festive sacrifice, as there are no indications for turning the animal towards the Kaaba during regular slaughter. Imam Ash-Shawkani said, There are no indications for this in the Quran or Sunnah. As for those who speak of the desirability of turning the animal towards the Kaaba before slaughter, by analogy with the festive sacrifice (Udhiyah), this analogy is incorrect, because desirability is a provision of Sharia law, which must also be proven. See Sailul-Jarrar 4/70.

On the desirability of personally performing animal sacrifice: In the authentic Sunnah, there are numerous indications that the Prophet (peace be upon him and blessings of Allah be upon him) personally performed his animal sacrifices. For example, Anas ibn Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him and blessings of Allah be upon him) personally performed his Eid sacrifice. Ahmad 3/188. The Hadith is authentic. See Sahih al-Jami' 4942. Quoting the words of Ibn Qudamah: If a person personally performs his sacrifice, this is better. Al-Mardawi said: There is no doubt about this, for the Hadiths indicate it. But even if a person does not slaughter his own animal, it is desirable for him to at least be present when it is slaughtered. See Al-Insaaf 4/83. Al-Musayyib ibn Rafi' narrated: Abu Musa al-Ash'ari (may Allah be pleased with him) ordered his daughters to personally slaughter their sacrificial animals. 'Abd al-Razzaq 4/389. Hafiz Ibn Hajar called the isnad authentic. See Fath al-Bari 10/19. By the way, this message indicates that women have the right to slaughter animals, whether it is for meat or for Eid sacrifice. This is permissible, despite the fact that many circles hold the opinion that it is not allowed. Ka'b ibn Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: Once a woman slaughtered a sheep with a stone and asked the Prophet (peace be upon him and blessings of Allah be upon him) about it, and he instructed her to eat it. Al-Bukhari 5504. Ibrahim al-Nakha'i regarding animal sacrifice performed by women and children said: There is no problem with this, if they are able to slaughter the animal and say the name of Allah. Sa'id ibn Mansur. Hafiz Ibn Hajar called the isnad authentic. See Fath al-Bari 9/575. Imam Ibn al-Munzir said: The scholars are unanimous that animal slaughter performed by children and women is permissible. See Al-Ijma' 43.

On mentioning Allah before sacrifice: Before sacrificing an animal, it is recommended to mention the name of Allah. The Almighty Allah said, So mention the name of Allah upon them when lined up [for sacrifice]. (Quran 22:36). According to the Sunnah, it is recommended to say the following words before sacrificing: Bismillah, Allahu Akbar. Allahumma taqabbal minni. which means In the name of Allah, Allah is the greatest. O Allah, accept from me! (Muslim 3/1557, Al-Bayhaqi 9/287).
texts.arabic: باسم الله والله أكبر اللهم تقبل مني

texts.text: On including family members in the sacrifice: A Muslim may also include members of their family in their sacrifice, just as the Prophet (peace be upon him) used to do. He would say,  O Allah, accept [this sacrifice] from Muhammad and the family of Muhammad. (Ahmad 6/220, Ibn Majah 3122). This hadith is authentic, and can be found in Irua al-Ghalil 4/352. In this case, during the slaughter of the animal, one should say, O Allah, this is from me and from the members of my family.
texts.arabic: اللهم هذا عني وعن آل بيتي

texts.text: Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) reported: “I performed the Eid prayer with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) on the Day of Sacrifice. After completing the prayer, he brought a ram and sacrificed it, saying: ‘In the name of Allah, Allah is the Greatest. O Allah, this is from me and from those in my community who did not offer a sacrifice.’ (Ahmad 3/356, Abu Dawud 2810, at-Tirmidhi 1521). This hadith is authenticated by al-Hakim, az-Zahabi, al-Haythami, and al-Albani. In this chapter, it is necessary to point out an error that some Muslims make when intending to sacrifice an animal. After reading hadiths like the one where the Prophet (peace be upon him) performed a sacrifice for himself and his community, they say: “O Allah, this is from me, from the Prophet Muhammad, and from the members of our community.” This is an error because sacrificing an animal for the members of the Islamic community was a special practice of the Prophet (peace be upon him) only, as noted by scholars. Sheikh al-Albani said: “What is mentioned in these hadiths about the Prophet (peace be upon him) sacrificing an animal for the members of his community was exclusively his practice, as mentioned by the knowledgeable Ibn Hajar in al-Fath (9/514). Therefore, no one else is allowed to follow him in sacrificing an animal for all the members of the community.” (See “Irua al-Ghalil” 4/354).

On washing before sacrificing an animal: This is something that many ignorant Muslims do, considering it desirable. However, this is an innovation that has nothing to do with the religion of Allah. The scholars of the Permanent Committee, led by Sheikh Ibn Baz, said: It is not reported from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he performed washing after the Eid prayer in order to sacrifice an animal. And nothing is reported from the righteous Salaf of the first three generations regarding this. And whoever performs washing for the purpose of sacrificing an animal is an ignorant follower of innovation! See Fatawa al-Lajnah 11/433. As for what some ignorant people do by washing the animal before sacrificing it, thinking it is part of the ritual, this is also an innovation that has no basis in religion, except for certain traditions of certain peoples.
